content: How can I help you today?

I’m here because my wife thinks it’s important for our family, but honestly, I’m skeptical. Things at home have been really tough with my son acting out, and it’s taking a toll on my marriage and my ability to focus on anything. I feel overwhelmed and don’t even know where to start.

It sounds like there’s a lot on your plate right now — trying to manage challenges at home, your relationship, and feeling overwhelmed. That’s a heavy load to carry. What do you feel would be most helpful to talk about today?

I guess my son is the biggest issue right now. He's been acting out a lot, and it's like my wife and I can't get on the same page about how to handle it. It's frustrating, and honestly, I feel like I'm failing as a parent. I don't even know what to do anymore.

Parenting in tough times can feel so overwhelming, especially when it feels like you're not making progress together. It sounds like you're deeply invested in being a good parent, even though you're feeling stuck and frustrated right now. What do you think has been the hardest part for you in dealing with your son's behavior?

I think the hardest part is not knowing how to help him. It feels like he’s just getting worse, and no matter what we try, nothing changes. It’s exhausting and makes me feel powerless, like I’m letting him down.

That feeling of wanting so much to help and not knowing how must be incredibly hard. It shows how much you care about your son and his well-being, but it sounds like the lack of progress has been really disheartening for you. What would it mean to you if you were able to find a way to support him and see some positive change?

It would mean everything. If I could help him and see some improvement, I think it might take some of the pressure off my wife and me, and maybe we could finally feel like we're getting somewhere as a family. I just don’t know where to start or if anything will even make a difference.

It’s clear how much you care about your family and how deeply you hope for things to improve. It sounds like you’re searching for a way to get unstuck and create some relief for all of you. What part of this situation feels like it’s within your control right now, even if it’s something small, to start making that kind of difference?

Honestly, it doesn’t feel like anything is in my control right now. I guess the only thing I can control is how I respond, but even that feels impossible half the time because I’m so drained. I don’t even know if I have the energy to figure this out.

It takes a lot of courage to admit how drained you're feeling, and it’s okay to acknowledge that this is hard. It also sounds like you recognize that your responses could play a role, even though you’re not sure where to find the energy to even start. What do you think could help you begin to feel a little less overwhelmed?

It’s hard to say. Maybe if I could get some clarity on what’s going on with my son, or if my wife and I could actually work together instead of feeling like we’re in separate corners. Even just one step forward would feel like a relief right now.

It sounds like having some clarity and teamwork with your wife might make a big difference for you. That desire for even a small step forward shows just how committed you are to finding a way through this. What do you think would need to happen for you and your wife to start working together more as a team?

I think we’d need to communicate better without it turning into blame or frustration. Right now, it feels like we’re focused more on what the other person is doing wrong instead of figuring out how to help our son together. I just don’t know how to start that kind of conversation without it turning into another argument.

It sounds like you really want to shift the focus of your conversations with your wife toward working together for your son, rather than feeling stuck in blame or frustration. That’s such an important insight. What do you imagine could be a good first step toward starting that kind of conversation in a way that feels different for both of you?

Maybe I could try to talk to her when we’re both calm, and just let her know that I want us to find a way to work together. I’d have to be careful not to sound like I’m blaming her, but honestly, I’m not sure how to say it without worrying it will spiral into another fight.

It’s thoughtful that you’re considering timing and your approach to avoid blame—that shows your intention to create a more constructive conversation. It can be hard to express yourself when emotions run high, especially when you’re worried about it escalating. How would it feel to take a moment beforehand to center yourself and focus on what you truly want to express? What might help you prepare to stay calm during that conversation?

It makes sense to approach it carefully. Maybe if I remind myself that the goal is for us to work together and focus on helping our son, it could keep me grounded. I could also write down what I want to say beforehand, just to sort out my thoughts and make sure I don’t come off as frustrated or defensive.

That’s a really thoughtful and proactive approach—writing things down can give you clarity and help you communicate in a calm and focused way. You’re also keeping the bigger picture in mind, which is working together to support your son. How confident are you feeling about taking this first step toward having that conversation?

I guess I feel a little nervous about it, but I know it’s important, so I’m willing to try. I don’t want to keep going in circles with her, and if this could help us move forward, it’s worth a shot. I just hope it doesn’t backfire.

It’s completely natural to feel a bit nervous, especially when the conversation matters so much to you. The fact that you’re willing to try, even with those feelings, really shows your commitment to improving things for your family. If you’re open to it, we could explore ways to help you feel even more prepared or confident as you approach this. Would it help to talk through any specific concerns you have about how the conversation might go?
